This experimental printer uses fishing line to suspend and move the print head in the workspace. The lines are all kept in tension by a spring-loaded tension pole that pushes down on the print head carriage. It is, in effect, a dynamic tensegrity (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tensegrity) structure. It looks kind of like a delta printer, but the kinematics are a little different. This is a great project for anyone wanting to spend a great deal of time figuring out how to build (and improve upon) a unique 3D printer. I know of a couple of other designs using a similar approach, so you might also want to check out:
https://designmakeshare.wordpress.com/2013/09/16/introducing-skydelta/
https://sites.google.com/site/3dprinterlist/delta-3d-printers/wire-suspended-deltas/flying-skydelta Watch the video: https://youtu.be/J6X3oLVhHF4

These instructions are far from complete, but they'll serve as a starting point if you are interesting in trying to build this printer. Just post any questions you have in the comments, and I'll try to fill in the gaps as we go. Keep in mind: even though I managed to get my printer working, it will take a lot of ingenuity on your part to to make your own. This project is not for the faint of heart! Frame
The frame is formed by laser-cut 6mm acrylic top and bottom plates (see DXF files) separated by 3/4" dia aluminum tubes (11" long) and clamped together with internal 1/4-20 threaded rod. The build platform is actually just the internal cutout from the bottom plate rotated by 60 degrees. It rests on three 10-32 leveling screws that are topped with 3D printed adjustment knobs and round rubber bumpers. Print Head Carriage
This printer uses a Bowden-type extruder, but instead of the filament being fed in-line with the extruder nozzle, it comes in at a right-angle. This is necessary because the tension post moves around in the area above the carriage and would interfere with the Bowden tube. The carriage plate is 1/16" aluminum plate (see DXF files). I won't get into the hot-end/extruder details here, but I can provide more information up request. Rigging
This is the most complicated part of the printer. It uses 30# test Spectra fishing line which has very little stretch. Each of the 3 sides of the carriage plate is supported by two separate lines, similar
to a delta-style printer. For any given side, both lines wrap onto a single 10mm dia. spool on the motor shaft. For one side, the line goes from spool, thru the eyelet on the upper plate, down through
the eyelet on the carriage plate, back thru the same eyelet on the upper plate, and then finally to an adjustment screw. It takes quite a bit of patience to get this strung up. Examine the photos and
video carefully to see how the lines are routed. Note that each line has an effective pulley reduction of 2:1 which doubles the positioning resolution. Eyelets & Adjustment Screws
The eyelets are formed from 0.035" dia hardened steel wire. I started by making a U-shape in the wire and then shoving the ends of the"U" through the holes in the carriage and upper plates. I then placed a thin spacer inside the "U" and folded the legs over to make sure that all the eyelets had exactly the same height. Finally, I cut off the excess wire with a Dremel cut-off blade. To prevent abrasion of the fishing line as it goes thru the eyelets, I slid a small piece of 0.022" ID teflon sleeve over the line at each eyelet. The teflon sleeve stays in place while the fishing line
slides through it. The very end of the fishing line is clamped between 2 nuts on the end of a 1" long 4-40 screw that is threaded thru the upper plate. Rotating the screw will wind up (or unwind) any excess fishing line.
This is the mechanism used to fine-tune the leveling of the carriage plate. The adjustment screw can then be locked in place with another nut against the upper plate. Tension Pole
The tension pole is a 0.292” dia, 18” carbon fiber tube that presses down onto the carriage plate to keep the strings in tension. At the bottom, it has a 1/2” dia. Nylon ball glued on that fits into a 3D printed cup. At the top, it has a cap with places to attach the tension springs. For springs, I've used 3” (active) lengths of 0.187” dia surgical tubing. Steel springs would probably be better, but the tubing is much easier for doing trial and error adjustments. I have the tubing stretched to about 6” when the print head is at the top. To keep the springs at more or less a constant tension, they are rigged with addition fishing line similar to the carriage plate lines. The line for each spring starts at the motor spool and is suppose to wrap up as the carriage lines unwrap. From the spool, the line goes thru an eyelet at center spacer, up thru the clip at the bottom of the spring, back down thru the same eyelet at the center spacer, and then to a clamping screw on the upper plate. Controller
I've used a Printerboard running Marlin for the controller. I configured Marlin for a Delta printer, but I modified the kinematic equations for this printer. Normally, the parameter DELTA_DIAGONAL_ROD is the length of the rigid arms for a delta printer. In this implementation, this parameter is the starting length of the strings when the print head it in the top-center position. marlin_files.zip contains the modified configuration.h, pins.h and marlin_main.cpp files I used. The one big unsolved issue is homing because there's no good place to put limit switches. My hack has been to use square knobs on the back of the motors. Before starting each print, I position each knob manually to exactly the same orientation so that the carriage is at its top-center position. This is the origin, and I set the Z-offset in my slicer to distance the table is below the nozzle tip (a negative number).

comments.text: This is a super interesting design, I'm surprised how well the prints came out. Good job for being creative :)
comments.author: Kavex

comments.text: You venture through the countless cubes toys and other items created to say you can do better then learn and create something you think is pretty useful and cool.. and assume you have grasped the complexity of both design and the machine hardware.. Then you come across a guy like you that blows your mind with the concepts.. the designs, foresight and skill.. You raise the bar pretty high.. Yours is the best collection I have seen so far..   LOBOCNC  by far..
comments.author: vesarious

comments.text: Thanks for your kind comments!  Keep in mind that I've been engineering for close to 40 years, and these days, I have way too much time on my hands:)
comments.author: vesarious

comments.text: I absolutely love this idea. I'm curious though, could you use a telescoping spring loaded center pole instead? thereby eliminating the height requirement? you could also run all the wires and filament down the center of it which removes the wagging tail most deltas have.
comments.author: Screwyluie

comments.text: You might be able to do it with a telescoping pole, but what you really want is a constant (more or less) downward force, and that'll be hard to get with a telescoping pole.  Also, given the relative flexibility of the Spectra line, you really have to be careful to minimize any friction.
comments.author: Screwyluie

comments.text: I can't wait your next design! You are so creative, respect to you.
comments.author: how_eee

comments.text: I saw this and I was like no. Then I watched the video and I saw the wires and bands tightning to make the hot end move and I was convinced. This has to be the coolest Delta printer ever

comments.text: Thanks!  As mentioned in some of the comments below, this particular printer is not hugely practical, and all of the strings are a bit of a nightmare.  However, I'm mulling over a much simpler, more practical design.  Stay tuned...
comments.author: Infinity_ac

comments.text: This is just ludicrously clever. My hat off to you, the fact that you conceived and created this, and got it to work as well as you have just blows my mind. Granted this is obviously not your first rodeo but even so, I'm gobsmacked. Would never have thought it was possible.
comments.author: theirishscion

comments.text: Hey, thanks!  Like most ideas, I've found that if you beat on them long enough, you can get them to work.  But also like most ideas, once you finally get it to work, you realize it's not quite as great an idea as you first thought.  I don't think this'll ever be a practical printer, but it was fun to get it working.
comments.author: theirishscion

comments.text: I don't think it matters much whether it's practical, what matters is that a concept was conceived, implemented, developed and assessed. Through this, all human progress occurs. I'm amazed at how fast you managed to remix emmett's Iris Box. Granted this is my first ever attempt at SCAD-tweakage, but it took me a healthy 20+ minutes to work out how to shrink the clearance between the outer spheroid and the base, plus another couple hours of trial and error tweaking the value and re-rendering at 120, all so I could generate a version that would print neatly at 150% with a clean stable junction. How on earth you managed to turn his design into your design in a couple of days I have no idea.
comments.author: LoboCNC

comments.text: Actually, I used Solidworks to redesign the Iris Box from scratch. I don't know how to use SCAD, and even if I did, it would probably taken me a long time to modify it. The emmett's basic design is beautifully simply, so using a powerful design tool like Solidworks makes life infinitely simpler.That said, sometimes I really wish I understood SCAD because sometimes Solidworks can be maddeningly frustrating.
comments.author: theirishscion

comments.text: This is a really interesting design. Are you going to continue working on it? How would you say this compares print-quality and build-cost wise to something like a kossel mini?
comments.author: lerouxb

comments.text: The print quality to cost ratio is great because the costs are down to the bare minimum (motors, controller, hot-end, some structural parts & hardware) and the print quality ended up pretty decent (although not stellar).  However, the design is finicky enough that I wouldn't want to use it as an everyday printer.  I designed it mostly to see how cheaply you could make something that actually printed.

This is a replica of the M-94 cipher device with accurate dimensions.
See http://maritime.org/tech/csp488.htm for more information about the M-94 (also known as CSP 488). Each of the wheels can be fabricated with original alphabet orderings by creating an scad file like so: use <m94.scad> REPLICA = false; scale([2, 2, 2]) wheel(17); There are 25 wheels, 1 .. 25, in the full set. Setting REPLICA to false makes a 3-D printable object. I am still in the process of refining the printable models to reduce the amount of time to print and achieving best readability of the letters. You can download a full set of 3D printable wheels (STL format) from all-wheels.zip.
Source code on GitHub.

Scanned with ReconstructMe and an Xbox Kinect at the Coney Island Scan-A-Rama booth at Danbury Makerfaire on Saturday June 8, 2013. It was the public debut of my new scanning rig- the Scan-O-Tron 3000, and the scans have been beautiful. I am about to kick off a Kickstarter for Scan-A-Rama and plan to open source my plans, so stay tuned. Coney Island Scan-A-Rama is a next generation portrait studio for the 21st century! In the grand tradition of amusement part portraiture, but updated for the era of 3D printing, this popup 3D portrait studio will be appearing at MakerFaires and in Coney Island throughout 2013. For more information or to order prints, please visit http://www.thegreatfredini.com/scan-a-rama I recommend printing at .27 or .1 mm layer height with no support. You may have to trim a couple bits of hanging plastic off, but this will look great with no support.

This is a remix of Makerbot's Paris building Thing: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30649 I've scaled it to 15mm and sectioned and hollowed the floors to make it suitable for miniature wargaming. Each floor will hold six stands of infantry. Roof and floors are removable,with a lip to interlock the pieces when put together.

I printed in PLA at 0.3mm. I printed with supports, which means you have to clean out material from the windows. Notes

  • This thing is BIG! It barely fit my flashforge's build plate. It could probably be scaled down a little and still work.

  • The hollowing process left the window material very thin {see the upper right side windows). I'm calling it battle damage :).

comments.text: Very nice! I might have to remix it with the windows open so you can see the figures from outside. :D

description.text: This is a strong (high load carrying) off road RC chassis. It is designed to crawl around carrying things and to climb very steep inclines. It has fully independent suspension and 1 motor at each wheel. You can see the 4wd version here: https://youtu.be/a39qIS8JGv4 and a little more of its rock crawling abilities here: https://youtu.be/-LaEoF4j1Rk and with the FPV Camera from the Tank upgrade: https://youtu.be/4jV0W-KFchE I have also included plans and mounts for a 6wd version. (If you build this one, the axles need to be closer together as it is skid steer. Squarish vehicles work better). It makes use of a different mount for the electronics (transversely instead of longitudinally mounted). It is skid steer, and makes use of an Aluminium tube for the chassis rail. This keeps weight down. I've included the Rhino files so you can modify it more easily to your application. INSTRUCTIONS: CONTROL ARMS/WISHBONES: You'll need some 5-6.5mm aluminium rods (drill the holes out to suit what you have). Smaller is better. RC: I used the cheapest of everything I could find, and went with 2x motor speed controllers, 1 for each side i.e. the left side motors are connected in parallel to one, the right side motors to the other. I use one stick of the RC controller to control the vehicle in an odd way: top left = fwd, bottom right = back, left bottom = spin left, right bottom = spin right and everything in between is turning left or right while going fwd or back. It doesn't take any getting used to. You could use an Arduino or similar of course, like I did for our off road SLAM robot. This chassis actually has some advantages over that one, but you'd need to modify the various carriers for the LIDAR. MOTORS: I used Dagu Wild Thumper motors (6V) and wheels and mounts. There are 34:1 Metal Gearmotor 25Dx52L mm (High Power) Code: MEC-30089. 4.3 kg-cm and 5.5 A stall. Make sure you tighten the screws attaching the gearbox to the motor (I use loctite to make sure they don't work loose. They come from loose from the factory). MOUNTS FOR MOTORS: Pololu 25D mm Metal Gearmotor Bracket (comes in pairs). The holes in the motor carrier (printed) align with these mounts BATTERY: I used a 3300 mAh NiMH 7.2V battery. If you go 6wd you might try a higher capacity LiPo, though you'll get a lot of the NiMH for the 4wd. SPRINGS: #157000003/22497 1/10 Model Car 85mm Adjustable Aluminum Shock absorber (2pc Blue) SPEED CONTROLLER: 2x #9261000018/32025 HobbyKing X-Car 45A Brushed Car ESC chosen for the rating (45A) and price. any brand with similar specs would do. Remember it is skid steer so you'll be loading the motors quite frequently

description.text: Since I have an older version of the NanoCube aquarium there is no flow diverter meaning that my fish get blown around and have problems feeding. The flow needed to be high though to reduce algae/increase filtration so this is it. It was made for a filter head of .78" diameter and is made at .8" to compensate for the small amount of error during prints.

Printing took me about 2 hours. The large hole is to fit onto the filter output and the smaller holes are to divert flow. There are 2 holes not fully drilled through and that is to give the option of more pressure and flow in the downward ports and less flow out and around the tank. These can be drilled through later if you decide to.
My parameters for this print were .25 layers and 2 layers for the perimeter with reduced infill so that the thin parts during the middle of the print would not bubble up and snag the head.

title: Video Transmitter backpack for DJI Inspire 1

description.text: There's lots of reasons to mount an extra camera on your Inspire 1: two-person FPV, flying a thermal or multispectral camera, etc. This makes it easy to package up all the video transmitter, power, and wires for a good, clean flying experience! This version slots into my mount system so the whole system requires no modification to your aircraft, but there's also a [Dual Lock version](). The two boards it hosts are a 600 mW 5.8 GHz FPV transmitter ($27) and a 12V voltage regulator ($9), along with space to hold the wires that connect everything. It's designed to be paired with the Inspire 1 Gimbal Mount, so that your camera can be stabilized from wind and aircraft motions, but the two parts also work fine separately. If you don't have access to a 3D printer, Shapeways can print it for you.

comments.text: Having tried a number of methods, the one that's worked best (meaning that not only has it not failed yet, but it's lasted a lot longer than the others) is drilling into the two battery leads and soldering leads, running those leads underneath all the adhesive covers in the battery compartment and out the back, then using whatever voltage regulator is needed for the accessory I'm flying.

comments.text: Hmm, hard to share from here. Basically, I drilling into the two metal prongs in the battery compartment that supply the main voltage (not the four little ones next to them) and soldered leads into the holes.  I ran those leads down and out the back of the compartment to a plug where I can attach whatever device with appropriate voltage regulator for that device.

This is a plate for the dual relay modules from China.   
There is room for the through hole pins inside the plate allowing flush mounting on metal surfaces.  
This plate is designed to be screwed into the mounting holes on the  360w 12v 30A PSU's. Mine is from Folger Tech but I would assume most of the oem's use similar tooling so it should fit PSUs from other sources.

Print Settings:
.3mm Layer
100% Infill Physical Dimensions:
51x40mm for the relay base
5mm tall
3.5mm of clearance for pins on bottom of relay board
4.25mm between the tongs for PSU screws (I use M4)
44.3-60mm mounting distance between screw holes on PSU. It needs to be printed as a solid brick of plastic so that you can drill and screw into it if needed to mount the board. You can also super glue the relay to the plate. The wings for mounting it to the PSU are designed for M4 screws.

title: E3D V6 Hinged Extruder Bracket & Clamp

description.text:
A hinged bracket designed to carry an E3D V6 extruder.   
This remix adds a hinge system that opens to approx. 90 degrees to allow easier/quicker access for maintenance.

Print it all at 0.2mm with 20 - 25% infill. Support material is advisable when printing the bracket section.   
The printed pin works well to fix the hinge - I found it best to keep it pretty rough on the clean-up.  
The clamp is locked by an M3 @ 20mm (or slightly longer) bolt and nut. If the bolt is slightly long just heat it and push it into the hole until you have enough clearance.

comments.text:

Happy Printing!

Another fun print just in time for Halloween. This design includes a printable head band, horn adapters and some devil horns. I designed it so you could make something other than devil horns and still use the head band. Included in the files is a PDF showing how to design the holes to accept the adapters. They have a taper and can be pressed into whatever you want to stick on your noggin. Antlers? Mouse Ears? Use your imagination. Printed on a PRINTinZ Flexible Printer plate https://www.printinz.com/printinz-3d-printer-plates/

comments.text: I love the swappable headband. You should use it to make the different versions that Star Butterfly wears.

title: A Gift for Parents --- Glasses Holder

description.text:
This is a glasses holder I designed for my father for his birthday gift. It is pretty funny and it works great. The two sets of "arms" can hold up to 2 glasses at a time, and the holes can actually let you design and add something on this holder to upgrade it. It is a perfect gift for your parents to keep their glasses safe :) .  
P.S. The diameter of the holes is 5mm.

description.text:
Support made for light objects. Tested with 900g and 2kg. But I don't recommend to use more that 400 grams since the final characteristics is very dependable of the print quality. PLA Ultimaker Original +
Nozzle 210ªC. Heated bed: 70ºC
Z layer: 0,1mm
no supoorts
print with the base in contact with the bed

September 20, 2015 While I was printing the loud mouth, there was support added to it without me including it, so I flipped the
LoudMouths to start with a wider base. MY MISTAKE. Also, I included a 50mm LoudMouth to do a blow test. I will give the results on my next update. Put the item in your mouth then blow. There are currently two sizes for your 3dprinter. The bigger the size, the louder it should be. The MouthPipe is recommended if you want to annoy people with two LoudMouths at once. The LoudMouth_160mm.stl is by itself. Comments is appreciated.
THANKS!!!

The MouthPipe will only fit with the LoudMouth_100mm.stl file. Unless you manage to scale it down to your specific size.  
The MouthPipe requires 2x LoudMouth_100mm on the front and top.

This is a project I had developed some time ago. I wanted a stand to floss make it as simple as possible, easy to wash s why no parts or devices. But how to develop this support, and would have to hold the floss tightly on the ends of it, so it could be used?
The solution was to take advantage of the flexibility of plastic. Thus, the two ends of the floss can be attached by the cord holder, ie, puts up the two ends of the wire in the middle of the cable, which is broken into two equal parts. When the person holding the bracket cable to use it at the same time is holding the two ends of the floss, simply squeeze it a little more.
Thus unable to develop supported in a single piece, and yet functional, taking advantage of the flexibility of the plastic which is the material has to be used.
Despite having developed the computer, I had to manually shaping the piece by hand in epoxy putty. After the copied part in resin using silicone molds. It happens that the resin loses its flexibility over time, s why it was not the right material for this support.
Now in possession of the printer Makerbot, redid the project on the computer, based on the last model produced by hand, as were several models initially, and got this, which besides being robust is anatomical, and small. For that reason they are comfortable to pick it up, and easy handling.
Naturally, there are several types of disposable floss holders, but there are still wanting to floss, so much that is still on the market. Moreover, these disposable media are more expensive, and are not comfortable to take them, because those round cables run in the fingers, and these must be hurt because squeezing harder, and are nothing anatomical feature by itself to be disposable.
But only use the floss is not convenient because it gets dirty hands and there is a certain difficulty in flossing teeth at all, having to put a hand on his mouth. Hence the need for a support for the dental floss that is simple and easy to wash.
Pity that now I can not use the printer Makerbot because it is having connection problems with your computer. For that reason they, the photo is the model I had produced artistically. In the main photo that appears, I made a montage to show their fucionalidade.
I offer support with two options to hold the floss between the cable division in two parts: first, this division presents smooth, and the second, with some ripple, aiming to give more efficiency to hold the floss.
I do not know how to behave in the two cases. I imagine that in the first case, on the flat, the two ends of the floss will be easier to put in, but require a little more pressure to arrest them. And in the second case, with the split corrugated, there is some trouble putting the floss between them, but it will be much more efficient in holding the two ends of the floss.
As I have no way to test it due to the problem of my printer, falls to those who download the files to be tested.
Who can, if possible, please send me a photo after they produce in their impressoras3D, so I can exhibit at Gallery Thinginverse.
The text was written in Portuguese, and automatically translated by Google Translator. Surely that reason they may leave a few words out of context, giving a slightly different meaning.
Who wants to get in touch, my email is [email protected] Changes in support for flossing in 19/08/2014
At the request of Stef suggested that a change in the support flossing, to make it more efficient to hold the floss, introduced some modifications accordingly.
The suggestion that was given is to add a button below the U-shaped portion, where the floss was wrapped, and thus be more effective in arresting him.
I thought of this suggestion, but found that putting a button on that site could disrupt the movement of the support inside the mouth, beyond that, could not be hygienic because the thong would look all luscious saliva. And then, one more element that location could be the focus of impurities.
Even so, I found a good suggestion, and decided to think how could using this suggestion, arresting more efficiently floss in support.
The solution was the following:
The button that the person suggested in part that would be introduced into the mouth, under the two ends, I put the tip of the cable (3), the outside (see figure ...).
In another part of the cable, insert a hole (1).
Made a slot (2) in the cable that goes from the knob, starting from the end and through the other side of this button (4).
Thus, when flossing this modified support, the person would make a knot at one end of the floss so that when passing the other end of the cable into the hole, it would be locked, and then the other end would the two tips support, return to bibartido cable, screwdriver and pass on the button, then it could be rolled. One or two turns is sufficient. The tip of the thong would be left, the person would hold with your thumb when holding the cable.
Surely with these modifications, the thong would be firmly attached in maintaining tension while doing the cleaning between teeth.
Stl file added to the modified support and in the blend form.

After lowering the files that are in the STL format, and produce support for flossing in their impressoras3D, one should be careful to remove the temporary structure if they use the program Makerware. Use pliers with tips for this operation.
The procedure to use think in images is described in Illustration 2, which is this:
1 - First, cut up the floss around 25 to 30cm.
2 - Double the thong in the middle, and fold it, passes underneath the bracket.
3 - Take this fold up the other side of the support, already at the top, and passes the wire in the grooves located on both sides of the two tips.
4 - arranges this to fold the two ends of the support following the existing groove therein.
5 - then pass the two ends through the cable split.
6 - Pull up the two points that appear behind the cable bracket, then secure them as well, holding the plug firmly, and is ready to be used.

Low profile spool holder for 2020 Misumi extrusion, similar in design to the Kossel compact Filament Spool Holder which inspired this version (Thanks Elliot for the suggestion). The spool fits over the small hub, and the hook drops in from the top to hold the spool in place. The hub is small enough for Taulman's mini spools, and short enough to fit in the stepped spools from Ultimachine and Atomic Filament. Requires a 10mm OD, 5mm ID, 4mm wide bearing and a 20mm M5 screw. There are two hooks, the magnetic spring hook is designed to be printed in a magnetic filament, with 5mm magnets in the insets. The regular hook doesn't require magnets. Press the sides of the hook while repositioning. I don't think there's any real reason to use the magnetic version, I just wanted an excuse to try out the magnetic iron filament. This design has enough resistance to prevent the spool from unwinding on its own, at least with the spools I've tried so far. Printer: (full list can be found on thrinter.com)
-- Eustathios Filaments: (full list can be found on thrinter.com)
-- Proto Pasta Stainless Steel PLA
-- Proto Pasta Magnetic Iron PLA

title: Solidoodle RAMPS adaptor with 80mm fan mount

description.text: This adaptor uses the factory M3 holes in the back of the (Sanguinololu based) Solidoodle printer to mount an Arduino Mega and RAMPS. An 80mm cooling fan can also be fitted to keep the resettable fuses and stepper motor drivers cool. This mount also offsets the electronics to provide clearance for the filament spool.

Print at high infill for strength.  
Assemble as shown in photos. You may need to elongate some of the holes to get them to line up with the Solidoodle holes, they are a tight fit.  
Fan on RAMPS is highly recommended if you have a fast heating bed that draws a lot of current. Without cooling the resettable fuses can trip causing a restart to be required.  
Dimensions in mm.

description.text: If you have a Micromake Kossel and you want to cool your bed separately to the hot-end you will require two fans, the one that comes with the kit is a 40mm so I started there.  This does not take up too much additional space and gives a lot of air to the bed without blowing on the extruder too much. If printing PLA I recommend that you activate the fan after a few layers have been put down so as not to shrink the adhesive layers too much.  I also made a clip-on fan for the E3D clone which I recommend to use together with this, see photos.  If you are going to make both, make the clip on one first so you can cool the hot-end fins.

Printed in PLA with flat side down
0.2mm @ 30mm/s
200c, hot bed off, used tape for adhesion I use Cura and gave it 15% fill and used support also but that might not be necessary. My pic shows an earlier print where I had the extrusion too low thus looks a bit grainy, I fixed that up though.

title: camera centering holder for cnc with 7mm shank

description.text: In order to properly center my edge finding camera on my cnc I created this simple 3 part camera holder. It has 7mm shank (can fit into ER11, ER16, ER20..) and will allow you to offset camera into any position in XY plane so you can properly center your camera in your toolholder.

print
assemble
mount your camera
push into toolholder
look trough camera on your computer, manually turn the spindle and offset your camera in XY plane so that center of the screen is always pointing in the same point on your workbed.
lock the holder in place with dab of glue or with touch of hot soldering iron

title: Filament Spool Hook for Deezmaker Bukobot

description.text:
There are fancy, multi-piece roller assemblies for holding your filament spool, or there is this: a hook.  One piece.  It snaps onto the frame of your Bukobot, and you're in business.  No magic printed bearings or axles.  No screws or fasteners of any kind.  Seriously.  It grips in and around the slots on the frame rails and totally just hangs there.  
"But wait, aren't smoothly gliding bearings important for printer performance?"  
"Eh, maybe? I don't know... this works, though..."  
Think of it this way: if your print head produces enough torque to stuff filament into the heated cup for extrusion, it certainly won't be back-driven by tugging filament off of the spool without a bearing.  
I put away the lazy susan (which you can still see in one photo) as this totally works and is what I use now.  The lazy susan spins freely, but requires the filament to bend around an extra 90 degrees on the way to the print head.  The extra bend was sometimes a problem for me with brittle filament.  
This is designed to fit spools with the 2.1" center hole.  
This is a sort of big piece, but if you have the printer this fits, you can print this piece.
Flat side down.  I made mine in PLA with 20% fill and 1mm shell.

comments.text:
Very good design and really "noisless" compared to a cheap LM8UU. Really tight IMHO, I had to work it internally with a M8 drill bit and then work it again until good and smooth fitting.
If you use it on the X ends/carriages take care of outer diameter (mine was 15.50 average after print, and LM8UU is 15.06).
Do not focus too much on the above reported "issues" because my prusa i3 is at its first prints and so it could be not perfectly calibrated.
I printed it with 0.35 nozzle and 0.2 layer height but the 1h16' spent is worth the result, the design is amazingly solid and survives even to heavy working with sandpaper.

I've researched many existing approaches to drill bit sharpening but did not find one that I like. I like simple and utilitarian designs. This is one of those: a one-piece guide for sharpening drill bits on a Dremel or similar rotary tool that uses an M19-2 thread. There are 3 guides included: 90, 118 and 135 degrees. The majority of people will need the 118* and for that the adapter comes in two sizes such that it can easily fit both small and large diameter drills, as well as different diameters in cutting/grinding disks. The adapter prints in one piece without support and is threaded to screw right onto the Dremel (I've tested it on my Dremel 285, 8000 and generic Alltrade tool which all happen to be 19mm thread size). It's also designed to accommodate mandrel upgrades. Addressing some comments:
Doesn't FIT - check your printer calibration, x/y/z steps/mm and slicer settings (filament factor or extrusion multiplier especially). Print a 20mm calibration cube and measure with precision calipers. Also check your material settings, many materials (esp ABS and PETG) tend to "tighten" when you print inside circles. Maybe resize it a bit (1-2%)? No Relief Angle - Yes I'm aware of the flaw. I'm going to try to re-design it some day, I wasn't expecting this to become so popular amogst the specialized people. I was in fact aware of the drill bit geometry and relief angle at the time of the design, it's actually a bit more complex than a single angle, but at the time decided to keep it simple and figured I'll add the relief by hand, you can actually see me doing it in the video. Feel free to tweak but note the non-commercial use, please contact me for a separate license if you are interested. https://youtu.be/Z6N5WAULoEM

I printed mine out of PLA, 0.2 layer, 33% infill. I printed multiple ones on multiple printers and seem to fit well, however printer calibration is critical. 
If you are worried PLA melting, then you're overheating your drill bit anyway (iow remember to quench the bits in water if they get too hot at the tip)

comments.text:
this drill jig has a major flaw. Since the V-groove in which the drill bit sits is in the same plane as the dremel axis your relief angle is zero. That way the drill will not penetrate the material easily. No good for drilling metal. Styrofoam might still work...You should study the proper angles of a drill bit tip like tip angle, relief angle, rake angle. Lots of sources in the internet. If you tilt the V-groove by 10 degrees out of the dremel axis plane the bits will cut much better.﻿
A precision grinding jig has 4 features:
1) an adjustable or fixed guide for the 118° tip angle, (present in your design)
2) an adjustable or fixed guide for the 5-15°relief angle. (present, but at disfunctional 0°)
3) an adjustable length stop for the bits. The adjustment screw allows to feed the bit into the grinding disc. (missing)
4) a means to lock down the bit's own rotation axis and allowing it to be rotated by 180° for the opposite cutting edge. (missing)
With those 4 features the tips will become perfectly symmetrical i.e. the point is exactly in the middle.

comments.text: The video is bad quality (focus ) and I'd have to redo it, but at around 1:15 mark there is a point where I give the relief angle. You have to do this free-hand though. I did think about making it complete and have rotating axis for the relief angle, as well as a perfect centering mechanism (for now you need to use a drill stop), but I decided in the favor of keeping the design as simple as possible. The intent was not to compete with the $200 drill bit sharpeners on the market (at least not in this revision :) ), but to make drill bit sharpening a bit more scientific that the completely random approach I was using before where I would free-hand the Dremel and wasn't even getting the same angle between left and right cutting edges.

comments.text: Be careful how much wear you put on the grinding disc. These discs (as well as thick grinding wheels) are meant to be edge loaded, not side loaded. Wear through the side of the disc too much, and the disc could "let go", into your eyes! Great design, but looks risky how the disc is loaded.
comments.author: davesuniquedesigns

comments.text: I would think everybody would use safety glasses whenever they use a rotary tool. And safety glasses should be sufficient to protect from a thin grinding disc. When bits of a broken grinding disc fly and hit my hand, the impact doesn't feel that strong--I would assume that safety glasses in good working condition would be sufficient to protect the eyes.
comments.author: davesuniquedesigns

comments.text:
Whats worth more your eyesight or a 2 dollar twist drill ??
safety glasses or not these cut off disks are NOT meant to be side loaded... EVER! They are not designed to allow side loading and its often where the centrifugal reinforcement is.
This design has a "hospital smell" about it
comments.author: davesuniquedesigns

comments.text: The picture looks like the reinforced cutting disc, in any case it is not meant to be used like that. I used the sanding discs, which is the far thicker one. Yes, excellent designs! Save me so much effort 'trying' to align the sanding of drill bits manually haha.
comments.author: davesuniquedesigns

comments.text: Always wear protection, irrespective of the load direction. The discs can shatter when loaded on the edge as well.
comments.author: davesuniquedesigns

comments.text: I saw this and actually came here to say the same thing as davesuniquedesigns.  It is a clever idea though.  If you brought it out a little more and angled it more you could use a cylinder grinding bit to get the same effect but much safer.  It would also give you the ability to use different grit bits to work on bits which are more heavily damaged.

description.text:
Having some basic Matrix math operations available in OpenScad has been a wonderful thing. I found my life to be somewhat lacking though because rotations are a royal pain in the... This thing adds Quaternion support to OpenScad Besides sounding like a cool name for an 80s rock band, or a futuristic diabolical planetary leader, quaternions are a math construct that make doing rotations a fairly painless task. basically: myquat = quat(axis, angle); So, to do a 30 degree rotation around the z-axis for example, would look like this: rotz = quat([0,0,1], 30); Now, that's not going to do you much good in OpenScad by itself, so you need to turn it into a matrix that OpenScad can easily consume and apply as a transform, so you do this: rotzmatrix = quat_to_mat4(rotz); Once you have this, you can use it with multmatrix() multmatrix(rotzmatrix); or multmatrix(quat_to_mat4(quat([0,0,1],30))); Ok, so wow, big deal!! OK. So, combinations can be done like this: q1 = quat([0,0,1],30);
q2 = quat([0,1,0], 15);
combo = quat_mult(q1, q2); multmatrix(quat_to_mat4(combo)); This will combine the 30 degree rotation around the z-axis, followed by the 15 degree rotation about the y-axis, or visa versa. This is nice, because you can apply this transform anywhere you like, without having to go through gyrations such as: rotate()
{
rotate()
} If you've used an instance of this math library in the past, I've made a couple of changes. I've added more vecxxx calls, to support vec2, and vec3 more explicitly. The biggest change is to the mat4 (matrix4x4) routines. Basically, I was storing the data in 'row order' previously, which required a transpose of the matrix before using it with the multmatrix() module. So, I changed the ordering to be column major ordering (for those in the know). That aligns better with what OpenScad expects, so life gets easier as you don't need the transpose in the end. At any rate, another batch of goodness for OpenScad. NOTE: the 'quat_to_mat4()' function is an interesting piece of work. The equivalent 'C' code utilizes a lot of variables, which are not a part of OpenScad functions (as opposed to modules). This poses quite a challenge. So, how it's broken down into a cascade of functions demonstrates a general methodology for dealing with 'variables' in functions. Just turn each 'variable' into a function. UPDATE: 22072011
I left a few routines out from the first release of this thing, so I've added them in:
quat_conj(q) - conjugate of the quaternion
quat_distance(q1, q2) - distance between two quaternions
quat_norm(q) - the 'length' if you will.
quat_normalize(q) - normalize the quaternion There is one more monster function to add: quat_slerp (spherical interpolation). As this one is more complex than the 'to_mat4', I'm having to think about it for a while. Not too bad, and it will come. Perhaps this will warrant a new version.

1) Download maths.scad and test_maths.scad
2) Play around with the test_maths.scad file to see how to use the thing
3) Use it
4) Rejoice! Quaternions are a big scary name. If you just change the name to "rotation thingy" life gets a lot easier.

description.text:
This is a remix of thing 11891  
By adding a 20mm ID collar to thing 11891, it is possible to use "plastic" M8 self aligning thrust bearings from Igus (RS part number 712-5011), these bearing offer very low friction and unlike the ball race type thrust bearings originally used with thing 11891 allow for miss-alignment compensation.  I also chose to use aluminium single beam couplings, which need to have the weight of the x-carriage supported so that the couplings do not stretch.

description.text:
Brackets for holding together four plates of wood to form an arcade joustick controller platform for one player.  
The bottom plate can slide out, so you don't need tools to assemble or open the box.

The design expects two MDF plates measuring 35x21 cm, one 35x2cm and one 35x5. This is by no means the perfect size, but I just went ahead with what I got. The 35mm width can be changed without altered the STL files. You want to start by measuring if your joystick and buttons will fit between the plates -- if not, increase the height of the two short sides in the Sketchup source as needed (same added height on both to keep the angle) and export as STL again. the current design seems to export without any issues using the more or less official STL plugin. The Sketchup source file includes a model of the wood plates and various stages of the bracket designs if you want to play with other sizes. I printed in PLA using a layer height of .24mm and an XY size compensation of -.12 to get the measurements as intended. You can scale a few percent up if the wood plate doesn't fit, and glue the brackets on instead od relying on friction. Note: The artwork on the image of the finished controller is not my own - it is a mildly cut-and-pasted part of the cool marquee from http://www.tomtilley.net/projects/arcade

comments.text: Nice idea! I've made a few arcade controllers myself. This is a great idea for trying out template layouts or dry fitting parts before assembly. Of course, if you don't have the tools, this looks like a nice clean alternative to mounting everything with screws or glue.

title: 'Cheat Sticks' - The easy way to keep your Chop Sticks under control!

description.text:
'Cheat Sticks' is a small Chop Stick alignment helper. Positioned correctly this subtle little helper maintains the distance between the Chop Sticks at the control / pivot point as well as minimizes side movement without affecting rotational movement (...required to grab food)  
Many people struggle with using Chop Sticks, particularly if you don't use them often to get in practice, so this  handy little slide on alignment helper could be just what you need. "Cheat Sticks have been designed to let you use Chop Sticks as they are meant to be used (i.e. The lower Chop Stick stays still and the top Chop Stick rotates up and down around a pivot point at the centre of your thumb). 'Once located correctly Cheat Sticks' minimises the sideways movement of your Chop Sticks... keeping them under control.   
Just slide 'Cheat Sticks' onto your regular pair of Chop Sticks to the point where you want your thumb located (approx. 2/3 of the length up from the tips). Hold the Chop Sticks in the correct way and your 'Cheat Sticks' will help keep them aligned as you use them.   
Most Chop Stick Helpers I've seen change the way Chop Sticks work because they either make them springy when moved from the neutral point or they link them at the top so turn them into giant tweezers. 'Cheat Sticks' are different in that they let you move your Chop Sticks in the correct way without any springy effect. They just help keep your Chop Sticks aligned.   
Tips for use:  
As Chop Stickers vary in size make sure you position your 'Cheat Sticks' at the point they still allow free rotation but minimize side movement (i.e. Locating 'Cheat Sticks' too far down the taper of the Chop Sticks will reduce their effectiveness as they Chop Sticks will be have increased potential to move sideways).  
If your Chop Sticks are very thick or thin you can adjust the Z-scale prior to printing to ensure a snug fit can be achieved to minimize sideways movement of the Chop Sticks. The standard file has been developed to suit most 'common' size Chop Sticks (6.75 to 7.25mm at the wide end).  
Rest your thumb on  'Cheat Sticks' to hold it in place but also try and keep the tip of your thumb so it can touch the top (moving) Chop Stick. This can further help with control.  
This is a quick and easy print that uses very little filament. Refer to the instructions and print some and try them out!  
Note: If you like this check out all my other designs.

  • Insert retainer on wheel with flat surface facing inwards.
    ( You may need to loosen / take the wheel of to do it ) ...

  • Center cap should have clips on the back, make sure they engage correctly on lip of ring.
    ( It may be easier to put on / take of cap while wheel is removed ) ...
    • Cheers, Bantum ...

This is a first draft, taken from an approximate measure up only ...

  • The white one is original - black copy.

  • You may need to trim / file down one end to fit correctly.

  • Subject to change, as I may need to rescan it later.
    • Ciao, Bantum ...

title: Sub33D recycled e-waste 3D printer v1.02 (large format, low cost)

description.text:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vPos9yfSatw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j0xPSoaX__0
  • Large format - print area: 300W x 280D x 230H
  • Low cost (utilising recycled e-waste)
  • Compressed aluminium tube frame and xyx-axis (extremely rigid, light weight)
  • Z-axis stabilisation incorporated in frame design, preventing z-axis vibration/movement under high x-carriage accelerations
    High power heat bed using cheap ceramic resistors (hence the two old PC power supplies)
    • Scaled up version has also been built, 400W x 300D x 400H Included Sketch-up design can easily be modified for different sizes etc (not limited by standard heat bed/linear bearing dimensions etc) Designed to utilise recycled printer, PC and general e-waste components which were supplied by Substation 33 (e-waste recycler here in Brisbane Australia) The total component cost excluding recycled components was around $200 AUD, major cost component came from nuts, bolts, screws and threaded rods New version 2.01 design has been completed and printed (currently under construction) new design focus was on maximising recycled components, price estimate for new v2.01 design is well under $100 AUD, will hopefully be uploaded within the next month or two My personal goal is to see some of the millions of PC's, office printers and general e-waste turned into 3D printers, enabling disadvantaged people access to very low cost 3D printers

Please watch "Sub33D 300x 280x 230 v1-02 Condensed build sequences 01-10" link for a rough overview Youtube video build sequence links (not complete): Sub33D 300x 280x 230 v1 02 build sequence 01 - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=E2a6cupmSsQ

author: Polpus

description.text:
Here's a little clamp for helping with picture frame glue ups. YouTube: https://youtu.be/i-NYl57XfNw Suggest printing in PLA with the following settings: 0.25mm layer height
30% infill
Overhang support Additional hardware items you will need are: 90mm of M6 threaded rod
1 off M6 nut
2 off M6 washers
2 off M3 by 20mm pan head screws The hole in the plunger needs to be tapped M6 and the threaded rod should be screwed in with some glue, such as 5 minute epoxy, to lock it in place. Whilst you have the glue out also bed the nut into the wings. The M3 screws go in from the bottom and cut their own threads into the top. They just need to bottom out and take care not to over tighten. I use packaging string. It is strong, does not stretch, and very cheap. String that stretches too much will not work as well. Hope you like this and it finds good use in your workshop.

author: Sixpm

description.text:
I am making electronics since years.. but never had a wiring pen (because the one you can buy are quite expensive for a piece of plastic). I have seen other designs in the internet but i made my own as you can see. But you can take a look here for other versions of a selfmade wiring pen:
http://www.instructables.com/id/Wiring-Pen/
http://www.vk2zay.net/article/208 how to use:
http://info.ee.surrey.ac.uk/Workshop/advice/grotwire/usingPen.html I used the first time a wiring pencil and don't know why i used it in the past. It is a very useful tool when making prototypes on stripboard. It speeds up the soldering very much. The design is made to fit different normal pen with different diameters. The pencil i used here hast a diameter of 10mm at his end but there is a little space left. Also its my first design made with tinkercad:
https://tinkercad.com/things/8cJFuIqMTbA
https://tinkercad.com/things/09uVoq5sOZn
https://tinkercad.com/things/iF4llk7EkKT

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

30

Notes: I printed with ABS. But is think PLA would have been better because its more solid.

Build it together Print 1x spool tube, 1x pen closure, 2x sidearms. Find a pen which fits to the pen closure. You need 4 screws like M4 to assemble everything. A spool with your favorite cooper wire. I glued the pen closure on the pen.
I also put a medic needle (hollow needle) at the end. With a little bit of shrinking tube I fix the the needle on the pen. And that's it!
Keep soldering :-)

micromake 3D Printing Auto Z-probe Effector V3 This effector was used on our last version of Micromake 3D Printer, and we're open sourcing the design to everybody.
This is the last version before we upgrade to injection molding, we perfected the design according to users' feedbacks. Aliexpress store ：http://www.aliexpress.com/store/2128317 kad 3d's review on our Micromake 3D Printer.

http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1016843
Version 2:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1024794 Whats Updated
Auto Z-probe Effector - Middle - More chamfering and beveling to make it more movable, this improve the compatability to lower resolution machines.
Auto Z-probe Effector - Clamps - Added flange to eliminate the necessity of a screw on the surrounding to hold it.
Auto Z-probe Effector - Surround - Added holes for nuts, rods won't fall out of place with long time printing like in the last version. To make it easier for the users, we provided the Gcode to print on our Micromake 3D Printer, you just have to copy the codes to a SD card, insert it to the machine and start printing. You might use the Open Source Marlin Firmware, or to use our special version firmware with auto z-probe functions together with Cura.
We integrated our firmware with Cura, making it easy to burn your firmware and launch the auto z-probe function.
After downloading Cura, you just need to burn the default firmware to the machine and start printing. For more information, please visit the link below. Default language is Chinese, however, English version is included. If you're interested in our products, please visit our website: http://umake.taobao.com
We're able to offer a low price for this product since we're based in China.
The cheapset version is only 999RMB (157USD).
For this price, you can get a 180mm printing surface with 350mm height. All the parts are injection molded, which means the dimension are very precised. We also have distributors around the globe, you can even find our products in many shopping websites. Thank you for your interest in our products, we will keep uploading our latest design. title: Audi A4 B8 2.0 TFSI PCV delete kit

description.text:
UPDATE : Catch Can - concept added - not complete!
Audi's have a few issues with oil consumption and Pcv valves,
So I've been working on a much cheaper - printed system instead of those $600 PCV delete kits that are around.
This is a work in progress and I'll be adding the parts as I finish them and test them.
So far the plug and locking end cap work great and have 50% of the PCV system bypassed. I will soon have the 2nd part completed along with a modular oil catch can.
UPDATE 2: Have added a new part to be placed between the rear PCV port to the turbo intake, this make the PCV completely disconnected from the engine (no more oil being sucked into the manifold or turbo intake - or coking valves and knocking octane points off your fuel) you will notice that smoke/steam will come from your PCV pipe now! this is no to be plumbed to an oil catchcan/filtration system. (this may not be legal in a lot of places)
This piece can be either printed in ABS (as it will need some heat resistance) or cut out of G10 fiberglass Anyone that would like to contribute to this project is very welcome to chime in. UPDATE: have added the start of the catch can (warning - these are untested and not complete - print only for concept)

print the plug in low to med res
support will be required for the O ring grove (you may need to change orientation so it is printed on its end. (hole side up)
fit 2 x 19mm O-rings (3mm thick)
this fits into the plenum chamber hose fitting where the PCV hose connects onto the manifold.
the endcap takes 2 x M3 bolts or screws to fit over the hose fitting holding the plug in place. by screwing the 2 M3 bolts in it will lock the cap to the pipe. It wont slip off as the barb of the pipe is larger then the screws locking it in place.
I did fit a small piece of foam in the inner face of the endcap so it wa a snug fit to the back of the plug. Soon to come is the catch-can with all fittings (less the actual hose)
this will include brackets to bolt it in the engine bay, hose barbs that will attach to the can itself. oil filter separator system and possibly a replacement PCV blocking plate.

comments.text: This is very interesting to me, I just got an a4 b8 and it seems to have the oil consumption issue. Can you point me to some more reading up on the topic?
comments.author: jonbayer

comments.text:
Yeah Audi won't do squat for you. So basically depending on how much oil you are using will depend on what needs to be done. Worst case new pistons, rings etc (big job)
But if not as bad you can do the plug and cap from here. The PCV is probably broken inside (there is a diaphragm inside that tears). That will help distill the oil from air as they naturally have high crank pressure, which is pumping the oil vapour into the intake manifold and then coaling your valves which decreases performance and idling.
But if you have hi oil consumption the engine is burning it and the only fix is the expensive one ... Sorry
If you have just recently purchased it I would suggest trying to return it. I spent $4500 doing the piston thing. Audi wanted $9k.
There are a few other things that can be done too. But you need to know what stage you are at.
177000 cars effected world wide.
comments.author: jonbayer

comments.text: hmm, how can I figure out what stage I am at? Shortly after purchase it asked for a litre of oil, and after providing it (5W40 castrol, VW 502 certified) it has been running for about 350km without complaint. Performance seems to be good, but I have no baseline for comparison. It idles without any noticeable complaint, no check engine light. I've got one of those bluetooth OBD2 readers, are there parameters I can check for insight?
comments.author: Anti-PASTA

comments.text:
Oil consumption is done by filling the oil via litres into the engine, you travel 1000 KMs then drain the oil and measure what is left.
The easy way is using the mmi system fill it so it is at the full mark. Set your trip meter and after traveling about 1000 KMs check the mmi oil level again. Normally from low(low oil warning to the full.mark )
Is 1 litre of oil.
Audi acceptable oil consumption is .5 of a litre of oil per 1000 km.
Ludacris I know. I was using 1ltr per 700km.
comments.author: jonbayer

comments.text: This looks great. Any plans to add a file for a full block off plate like the ones that come with the catch can kits?
comments.author: Msellers93

comments.text:
Audi's have high crank pressure naturally, so you can't just block it off. Best way is use the existing PCV then into catchcan and out to atmosphere (not really legal)
There is also a hose from back of PCV to the turbo, you can make a simple block off plate here.
You need to either block the intake manifold line or plumb it back to the catchcan.
I haven't done much with the catchcan design. I just modified an el-cheapo one.
I also glued in a 90deg elbow into the PCV to connect a 1/2 inch hose onto, then to the catchcan.
comments.author: Msellers93

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/lVvqJtRUET4

First 3D model I made.
Sculpted in Blender.

My daughter wanted a fence to make pens for her plastic animals. So I designed and printed something for her. As a beams, use standard 3 mm struts. The ToyFence_center parts make them stand up. The ToyFence_end part is attached with hot glue or superglue. The ToyFence_Conn_* parts are connectors of various kinds, allowing to make bigger pens.

A Remix for my dials with a 8mm shaft.
This is very usefull to calibrate your DaVinci 1.0.

shuriken_w = 4
shuriken_dia = 47.5

I have an Overlord Pro printer which has a lot of issues. I searched Thingiverse for a usable test model set. Finally I have found one but the files in it was completely unusable. I get the model measures and remodelled them in OpenSCAD. Since the idea is not mine I share all the files here. Happy calibration! EDIT:
  • Added cylinder and wall tests as well.
  • Corrected cylinder walls (were half of the desired thickness).
    V2.1
  • Added tall and wide blocks and cylinders. Print them with RAFT.
    • After a big repairing of my printer I started to calibrate it again.
  • The bed leveling is good, the external sizes are acceptable an every directions.
  • The holes are too tight.
  • Stringing is very strong.
  • Some ringing and pillowing can be seen.
    • I had a lot of things to do but the calibration model did a good job ;-)

comments.text: Hi, thanks for your fixes to my models. I hope you have seen my comment on the original page regarding my lack of updates. I will be interested to see how your dimensional accuracy compares to my first few tests (admittedly a while ago now!)
